<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate how partly covering the surface of the water in a beaker affects the rate at which the water cools.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 576, 137]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 145, 751, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 382, 534, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 421, 885, 600]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 611, 301, 629]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[601, 611, 673, 629]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 144, 661]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 643, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker and cover half of it with lid \(\mathbf{A}\) as shown in Fig. 1.2. This leaves \(50\%\) of the water surface uncovered.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 175, 706]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 688, 920, 721]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer into the hot water and record, in the first row of Table 1.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stopclock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 735, 173, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 735, 920, 768]]<|/det|>
Record, in the table, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(60 \text{s}\), \(90 \text{s}\), \(120 \text{s}\), \(150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 782, 175, 800]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 782, 467, 800]]<|/det|>
Pour the water out of the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 812, 920, 829]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> Repeat (a), using lid \(\mathbf{B}\) instead of lid \(\mathbf{A}\) to cover more of the beaker as shown in Fig. 1.3. This leaves only \(25\%\) of the water surface uncovered. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 117, 181, 135]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 673, 135]]<|/det|> Complete the headings and the time \(t\) column in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 136]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 149, 539, 167]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 175, 752, 483]]<|/det|>

\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 146, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 500, 180, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 500, 887, 515]]<|/det|> Write a conclusion to this experiment, stating for which lid the cooling rate is greater. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 515, 599, 532]]<|/det|> Explain your answer by reference to your results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 670, 180, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 670, 920, 701]]<|/det|> Suggest a change to the apparatus that could produce a greater difference between the rates of cooling for lid \(\mathbf{A}\) and lid \(\mathbf{B}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 700, 687, 717]]<|/det|> Explain why the change might produce a greater difference. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 731, 917, 749]]<|/det|> change .................................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 794, 917, 810]]<|/det|> explanation ......................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 839, 920, 858]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A student thinks that the cooling rate is directly proportional to the percentage of the surface area uncovered. He wants to draw a graph of cooling rate against the percentage of uncovered area to investigate this.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Describe how his graph line will show whether the cooling rate and the percentage of surface area uncovered are directly proportional.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 144, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 697, 260]]<|/det|>
Students in other countries are carrying out the same experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 860, 291]]<|/det|>
Suggest a factor that they should keep the same if they are to obtain similar readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 670, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate a circuit containing resistors. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 410, 121]]<|/det|> The circuit has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 687, 136]]<|/det|> The fixed resistor must remain connected throughout the experiment. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 425, 152]]<|/det|> Resistor \(\mathbf{X}\) has a resistance \(R = 1\Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 576, 183]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 191, 712, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 396, 532, 415]]<|/det|> [b]> 2.1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 144, 446]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 428, 282, 445]]<|/det|> Switch on. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 444, 920, 479]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the value of the current \(I\) in the circuit and the value of the potential difference \(V\) across resistor \(\mathbf{X}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 476, 282, 492]]<|/det|> Switch off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 175, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 611, 523]]<|/det|> Replace resistor \(\mathbf{X}\) with resistor \(\mathbf{Y}\) of value \(R = 3\Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 521, 437, 538]]<|/det|> Repeat the above procedure. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 175, 570]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 552, 621, 570]]<|/det|> Replace resistor \(\mathbf{Y}\) with resistor \(\mathbf{Z}\) of value \(R = 10\Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 567, 437, 585]]<|/det|> Repeat the above procedure. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 602]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 613, 539, 631]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 640, 838, 780]]<|/det|>
Resistor\(R/\Omega\)\(I/\)\(V/\)
X1
Y3
Z10

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 781, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the image produced by a converging lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 122]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 201, 150]]<|/det|> triangular <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 151, 166]]<|/det|> object <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 144, 880, 234]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 252, 532, 271]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 146, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 282, 667, 301]]<|/det|> Measure and record the height \(h_{\mathrm{o}}\) of the triangular object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 312, 918, 331]]<|/det|>
h_{\mathrm{o}} = .................................................... cm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 330, 358, 348]]<|/det|> • Switch on the lamp. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 361, 798, 376]]<|/det|> • Set the distance between the triangular object and the lens, \(u\), to \(30.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 375, 816, 392]]<|/det|> Move the screen until a clear focused image of the triangular object is seen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 390, 693, 408]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the height \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) of the image. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 421, 175, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 421, 823, 440]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure for \(u\) values of \(35.0 \text{cm}\), \(40.0 \text{cm}\), \(45.0 \text{cm}\) and \(50.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 453, 176, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 453, 358, 472]]<|/det|> Switch off the lamp. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 484, 539, 502]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 510, 680, 717]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 781, 91]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the force needed to **just** slide a block across a surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate how the force needed varies with the mass of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 398, 168]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 675, 199]]<|/det|>
a light, flat wooden block fitted with a hook as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 509, 229]]<|/det|>
a pulley which can be clamped to a bench.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 250, 771, 364]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 377, 532, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 409, 324, 428]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 495, 459]]<|/det|>
● list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 471, 767, 490]]<|/det|>
● draw a clearly labelled diagram of how the apparatus will be arranged

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 503, 630, 522]]<|/det|>
● give brief instructions for carrying out the experiment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 534, 801, 552]]<|/det|>
● describe any precautions which should be taken to ensure reliable results

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 565, 520, 583]]<|/det|>
● suggest a graph which could be drawn.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 596, 522, 613]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.
